trial_identification.studytitle: Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy for Agoraphobia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy for Agoraphobia involving a cognitive component: a comparative trial

interventions.interventions: Treatment of agoraphobia by using virtual reality exposure and cognitive therapy. Virtual reality exposure involves the confrontation of the agoraphobics with 3D real time computerized phobogenic situations. Cognitive therapy implies the use of cognitive therapy techniques (cognitive restructuring). Both are administered by a PhD student in clinical psychology. Protocol : 1 weekly session of 1 and a half hour for 2 and a half month (total 10 sessions : 2 of cognitive and 8 of virtual reality exposure)
interventions.comparator: Virtual reality exposure therapy alone. Protocol : 1 weekly session of 1 and a half hour for 2 and a half month (total 10 sessions : 2 of neutral conversation and 8 of virtual reality exposure).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety Sensitivity Index ASI (Peterson 1993). This instrument is a 16-item questionnaire which rate the fear of anxiety-related symptoms
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At Baseline, after last therapeutic session and 6 months Follow Up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Agoraphobia cognitions questionnaire ACQ (Chambless 1984) is 5 points scale questionnaires comprising 14 items to rate the intensity of thoughts regarding agoraphobia cognitions.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At Baseline, after last therapeutic session and 6 months Follow Up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mobility inventory for agoraphobia MIA, part 1 (Chambless 1985). This a 5 point Likert scale rating the severity of behavioural avoidance of situations dreaded by the agoraphobics
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At Baseline, after last therapeutic session and 6 months Follow Up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Behavioral Avoidance Test BAT. Classic objective behavioural measures of phobia intensity and clinical progress.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At Baseline, after last therapeutic session and 6 months Follow Up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Depression Anxiety Stress Scales DASS 21 (Lovibond 1995) is a 21-items subjective questionnaire that uses a 4 point scale to measure mood and depressive symptoms, anxiety and stress
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At Baseline, after last therapeutic session and 6 months Follow Up

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of Agoraphobia with or without Panic disorder
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: pregnancy, epilepsy, severe organic condition, Heart arrhythmia, vestibular syndrome, substance abuse, discontinuation in the psychiatric treatment, psychosis (schizoid or not schizoid) and absence of competence in use of English

trial_design.concealment: Participants will be recruited through different and various means.Diagnosis procedure will involve experienced post graduate psychology students under the supervision of a Clinic Director. Following the diagnosis, Allocation concealment will be achieved by using sealed opaque envelopes addressed to the researchers.
trial_design.sequence: Each participants will be characterized by a specific number and this code will be feed in a randomization table created by a computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Agoraphobia, a quite common anxiety disorder in Australia, is defined as the fear of being in places or situations from which escape might be difficult or embarrassing. Standard exposure therapy is not bereft of weaknesses. Hence, new research lines study the virtual reality exposure therapy. Virtual reality allows patients to interact in real time 3D computerized worlds. The project will include a sample of volunteered patients suffering from agoraphobia who will be exposed to virtual environments specifically created for the present study using an affordable game editor. This collaborative efforts goal is finally to search for a better understanding of agoraphobia innovative treatment and to discover presence objective measure instruments.
